title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Brief Description:  
 Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Art Forum featuring Sally Morgan Lehman
description:
The Department of Art & Design presents the Spring 2026 Art Forum series. Art Forum is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum.   
   
 The next speaker in this engaging series is curator Sally Morgan Lehman, founder and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in Chelsea, New York. Lehman will discuss her latest curatorial work on the exhibition  Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts , on view at the George Segal Gallery. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who previously taught in the Department of Art & Design,  Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  celebrates the creative achievements of twelve accomplished alumni working across figurative and abstract painting, photography, mixed media, video, and installation. The exhibition is on view February 3 through May 3 in the George Segal Gallery. 
   
 Sally Morgan Lehman has a diverse background in the visual arts, including museum education, exhibition design, public art placement, and private and corporate collections management. She is an active member of ArtTable, POWArts, and NADA, and has served as a visiting critic and juror at Wave Hill, Guttenberg Arts, the Wassaic Project, and the Hunter MFA program. Lehman regularly participates in panels on contemporary art and is a frequent guest speaker for art and art history students at FIT, The New School, and Pratt Institute. 
   
 Founded in 2002 by Sally Morgan and Jay Lehman, Morgan Lehman Gallery is a contemporary art gallery representing a small group of emerging and mid-career American artists working across a wide range of media, with a focus on women practitioners. The gallery has presented critically recognized exhibitions, with artists receiving coverage in The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal, The New Yorker, Art in America, Hyperallergic, and The Brooklyn Rail. 
   
 This speaker series is free and open to the public. 
   
 📅 Art Forum 
 Monday, 2/9/26  5:20pm-7pm 
 George Segal Gallery

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: Art Forum with Sally Morgan Lehman
location: George Segal Gallery, 4th Floor of the Red Hawk Deck
description:
Admission is free, open to the public.  Learn more about this exhibition 
   
 Art Forum  is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum, hosted by the Department of Art & Design. Curator Sally Morgan Lehman will lead a walkthrough of the exhibition  Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts. 
   
 Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  is a group exhibition presented by the Office for Development and Alumni Engagement and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together twelve accomplished alumni working in a range of media. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City,  Carpe Diem  highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Featured artists include Flávia Berindoague ’13, Bisa Butler ’05, Jonathan Calm ’97, Kyle Coniglio ’10, Alyssa Fanning ’12, Allen Ginsberg (1943), Márta Kucsora (2005–06), Michael Manning ’11, Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, William Pope.L ’78, and Maria Valdivia ’24.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace. 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 No registration required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and when?

 Tuesdays 3 PM - 4 PM, Wednesdays 6 PM - 7 PM, and Thursdays 2 PM - 3 PM

title: Getting Started with EndNote
description:
Using a citation manager like EndNote to organize your references has numerous advantages, including but not limited to... 
 
 Collect references as you browse the web or databases 
 Organize, highlight, and annotate your PDFs, all in one place 
 Sync between your devices 
 Automatically rename PDF files you've downloaded 
 Generate citations instantly and change style formats with a few clicks 
 
 This is a hands-on workshop, so please bring your laptop with you. By the end of this workshop, you will be able to import your existing references into the program, collect references from the library databases, and be able to generate citations using the "Cite While You Write" plugin. 
 If you can, please download the EndNote installation files in advance from the  Software Repository . 
 
 Related LibGuide:  EndNote by Siobhan McCarthy 
 Register Here:  https://montclair.libcal.com/event/16326126

title: The Montclair State English Department Presents: Mira Jacob
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
Tuesday, February 10th, 2026 at 4:30 - 5:30 pm in The Feliciano School of Business (Room 140), Ms. Jacob will offer a few words about the importance of literature in our contemporary moment before reading from her new book. She will then take questions from the audience. 
   
 
 
 Ms. Jacob is the author of The Sleepwalker's Guide to Dancing (2014) and Good Talk (2019) as well as the forthcoming We Killed Anji Alexander. Good Talk was shortlisted for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and it was named one of the best books of the year by the New York Times, Time, and other prestigious publications. Ms. Jacob has also written nonfiction for The New York Times, Vogue, and Guernica among other notable outlets. She is also an Assistant Professor of Writing at the New School.

title: Love is in the Charcuterie - JOIN RA JILL

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
Our guest this week will be Mr. Kevin Johansmeyer, an alumnus of Montclair State Physics & Astronomy, and currently a physics teacher at Passaic County Technical Institute. Mr. Johansmeyer will share his journey through the science of physics and a career pathway into science teaching, particularly through his experience as a Montclair State University student - just like you! 
 The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Immersive Residency Program Cali Midweek Series with PAQUITO D’RIVERA
description:
Cali Immersive Residency Program Cali Midweek Series: Cali Conversation and Performance with PAQUITO D'RIVERA and Cali School of Music Jazz Studies Area Coordinator Dr. Oscar Perez Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music FREE – Reservations Suggested 
 CUBAN-AMERICAN SAXOPHONIST AND CLARINETIST Cali Immersive Residency Program On Campus: FEBRUARY 9–13, 2026 
 Full Immersive Residency Schedule 
 Paquito D’Rivera  is a celebrated Cuban-born clarinetist, saxophonist, and composer whose genre-defying career spans Latin jazz, classical music, and beyond. Winner of 16 Grammy and Latin Grammy Awards, he was a founding member of Irakere and Dizzy Gillespie’s United Nation Orchestra, and has recorded over 40 solo albums. A child prodigy and son of classical saxophonist Tito Rivera, he has performed with major orchestras worldwide and composed for top ensembles including Yo-Yo Ma and Imani Winds. Also a writer and producer, D’Rivera is known for his eclectic style and for championing Latin musical traditions on the global stage.

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

This session emphasizes critical thinking and analytical skills relevant to forensic, medical, and diagnostic pathways.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Getting Started with EndNote
description:
Using a citation manager like EndNote to organize your references has numerous advantages, including but not limited to... 
 
 Collect references as you browse the web or databases 
 Organize, highlight, and annotate your PDFs, all in one place 
 Sync between your devices 
 Automatically rename PDF files you've downloaded 
 Generate citations instantly and change style formats with a few clicks 
 
 This is a hands-on workshop, so please bring your laptop with you. By the end of this workshop, you will be able to import your existing references into the program, collect references from the library databases, and be able to generate citations using the "Cite While You Write" plugin. 
 If you can, please download the EndNote installation files in advance from the  Software Repository . 
 
 Related LibGuide:  EndNote by Siobhan McCarthy 
 Register Here:  https://montclair.libcal.com/event/16326137

title: Spanish Writing Center -Workshop Series - Online - February 2026
organization: Center for Latino Heritage & Spanish Language Excellence
description:
How to Use Subjunctive with Verbs & Expressions of Emotions 
 This workshop offers a clear and practical introduction of the subjunctive, with special attention of its use with emotive verbs. Through examples and exercises, it explains when and why the subjunctive is used, and compares it with the use of the indicative, highlighting the changes in meaning depending on the verbs. Ideal for students who want to strengthen their understanding and use of the subjunctive in real contexts.

title: Career Ready with AI
description: Prepare for the modern job market by learning how to use technology and artificial intelligence to your advantage. This workshop explores AI-driven tools for job searching, networking, interview preparation, and resume development. Participants will learn how to use platforms like Canva, Google, and AI editors to design, edit, and tailor resumes while strategically presenting their skills and experiences. Discover how AI can help you tell your professional story with clarity, creativity, and confidence— so you can stand out in a rapidly evolving career landscape. title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Learn proper lifting technique, get personalized form checks, and master the basics of creating your own effective workout programs. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Thursday: 4-5PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where?

title: Bloomfield Pop-Up Pantry
description:
Pop-Up Pantry @ Bloomfield College ! 
 The Pop-up Pantry at Bloomfield college will provide free food and essential personal care items to students. Stop by to pick up fresh produce, canned items, household supplies, milk, deli meat, frozen meals, cereal, feminine hygiene products, toiletries and much more, all at no cost! Our goal is to ensure everyone in our community has access to nutritious food and everyday essentials. 
   
 Visiting the Pop-Up Pantry: 
 1) Please have your Event Pass, CWID and have a  PantrySoft Registration .  2) Please bring your own shopping bag and ID card! 
   
 ***Visitors are welcome to visit the Red Hawk Pantry once per week, including visits to the Montclair Pantry.*** 
   
 Our Mission:   
 We aim to address food insecurity across Montclair State University. The Red Hawk Pantry is open to all students, staff, and faculty at no cost. If you are unable to visit during our regular hours, please reach out via email at redhawkpantry@montclair.edu  
 Stay updated by following us on Instagram: @montclair_redhawkpantry 
   
 Date and Time: Thursday, February 12th 2025, 4PM to 6PM

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: I AM | Camille A. Brown & Dancers
description:
Five-time Tony nominated choreographer and director Camille A. Brown deepens her explorations of Black joy in Camille A. Brown & Dancers’  I AM . With captivating live and original music,  I AM  launches new queries into the possibilities of imagination—and boldly investigates the future. Inspired by a narrative within HBO’s  Lovecraft Country  and the rhythms of the movie  Drumline , Brown’s 2025 New York Times Critics’ Pick breaks boundaries and “takes her signature interweaving of African diasporic dance forms to new heights.” —  The New York Times 
   
  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Be CAST's Valentine
description:
CAST wants to show their love and has a Valentine for you! 
 Attend any CAST service on February 12th or 13th and stop by the tutoring center front desk to receive a Valentine from CAST. 
 Students looking for academic support for their classes can attend both appointments and walk in services.  
 Academic Support available in: 
 Peer Tutoring : Meet with our student tutors for a one on one tutoring session based on your specific classes for the semester. Appointments can be in person in the Sprague Library, our Dinallo tutoring room or virtually through zoom. Appointments can be booked in  Navigate . 
 Supplemental Instruction :   Weekly peer-led review sessions for historically challenging courses . Supplemental Instruction leaders are embedded in the classrooms and offer no appointment needed, group visits. Schedules can be found in  Navigate  or on our website. 
 Peer Academic Coaching :  Talk with our coaches about the tools for success in your college classes and build an individualized plan for your own, time management, note taking and study strategies. 
 Workshops : Attend our workshops to learn more about resources on campus and tips for academic success. Workshops are offered both in person and virtually. 
   
 Schedules and locations for all tutoring can be found in  Navigate  and our Workshops on  Engage

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: Know Your Rights: ICE Rapid Response Training & Community Solidarity
description: Join us in partnership with Cosecha New Jersey for an important and practical training session on ICE Rapid Response and Immigrant Rights. This event will provide critical information on what to do during an immigration raid, how to document encounters safely, and ways to support and protect vulnerable community members. Attendees will also participate in folding “Know Your Rights” (KYR) cards to distribute locally. This training is open to all students, staff, and community members interested in advocacy, immigration justice, and direct action. No prior experience necessary—just a willingness to learn and support. Let’s come together to educate, organize, and stand in solidarity with immigrant communities.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Sandro Russo, Piano Masterclass
description:
We are privileged to have  pianist Sandro Russo  teach a piano Master Class in Leshowitz Recital Hall. This will take place from 12:00pm until 2:00pm on  Monday, February 16, 2026 . All are welcome. Reservations are not necessary. 
 Born in San Giovanni Gemini, Italy,  Sandro Russo  displayed exceptional musical talent from an early age. After entering the Vincenzo Bellini Conservatory, from where he graduated summa cum laude, he went on to earn the Pianoforte Performing Diploma with honors from the Royal College of Music in London. Mr. Russo has since gained attention for an extensive repertoire that is comprised not only of well-known masterpieces from all periods but also of rarities of the piano literature.

title: 2026 Black Alumni Advisory Council Black History Month Career Panel
location: University Hall 1050 - Ingrid & Scott Williams Lecture Hall
description:
Heirs and Architects of a Great Legacy: Black History Month Alumni Event 
 In partnership with the African American Caucus and the African American Studies Department at Montclair State University, this special Black History Month event celebrates our history while providing tools to elevate your career. Join us for a unique opportunity to connect and network with accomplished alumni across diverse industries, united by the strength of family and community legacy. Hear from a panel of professionals who will share valuable insights to guide your career journey. Let their stories inspire and empower you to take your next step forward. 
 Event Details 🗓  Date:  Monday, February 16 ⏰  Time:  4 – 6 p.m. 📍  Location:  University Hall 1050 - Ingrid & Scott Williams Lecture Hall 💰  Cost:  FREE 📝  Registration:  Required (Sign up now!) 
   
 What’s in it for you? 
 
 Career Panel featuring alumni in the social services, business and the sciences 
 Networking with professionals who’ve been where you are, and who are now empowering others with their knowledge 
 Tips for launching your career and navigating your next steps 
 Direct access to alumni who are crushing it in their fields, showing the power of roots and wings in action 
 
   
 Meet the Panelists 
   
 
 Dr. Ty’ya Pettis ‘22 MBA  is Director of Strategic Marketing & Communications at Woodmont Properties and President of the American Marketing Association New Jersey Chapter. She holds an MBA from Montclair State, an MS from NYU, a BFA from Kean and a Doctorate from Rutgers focused on socially responsible corporate communications. She serves on the Rutgers Marketing Advisory Board and Diversity Action Alliance Council, and is passionate about mentorship and empowering the next generation of business leaders. (Dr. Hubbard's daughter!) 
   
   
 
   
 Dr. Tawanda Hubbard ’00, ’25  is an associate professor of Professional Practice at Rutgers School of Social Work, where she has spent 14+ years mentoring justice-minded social workers. She holds two doctorates, a Ph.D. in Family Science from Montclair State University and a DSW from Rutgers, plus an MSW and a BS in Business Administration. A licensed clinical social worker with 20+ years of experience, Dr. Hubbard owns a private practice and consulting firm. She is a recognized leader in social work education, diversity and community service, including past and current roles with NASW–NJ, NABSW–NJ and the Rutgers Alumni Council. (Dr. Pettis' mother!) 
   
 
 Dr. Reginia Judge, Esq. ’89  is an associate professor in the Department of Justice Studies at Montclair State University. She earned her Juris Doctorate from Seton Hall University School of Law and served as Assistant County Counsel for Hudson County. Her academic journey began over three decades ago as an adjunct professor at Hudson County Community College, where she studied as an EOF student, majoring in English with a minor in Paralegal Studies. She joined MSU’s faculty 30 years ago and has since taught ten legal specialty courses and eleven criminal justice courses, covering both civil and criminal litigation. (Ms. Munn's sister!) 
   
 
 Lee Nina Munn ’92  earned her Bachelor of Science in Communication Sciences and Disorders and completed her Teacher of the Handicapped certification in 1995. She currently serves as a full-time Transition Coordinator with the Newark Board of Education, helping students with intellectual, developmental, and physical disabilities move confidently from school to adulthood. In this role, Ms. Munn designs individualized transition plans that connect students and their families with resources for job readiness, continuing education and independent living skills. (Dr. Judge's sister!) 
 
 Jasmine Metellus '21  is a dynamic leader and advocate born in Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and raised in Irvington, New Jersey, whose work centers on representation and community empowerment. She serves as Politics and Government Relations Manager for the New Jersey League of Conservation Voters and is President of the Essex County Young Democrats. Her experience includes roles as Chief of Staff to Senator Renee C. Burgess, Legislative Aide to former Assemblywoman Sadaf F. Jaffer and a member of Governor Phil Murphy’s 2021 campaign team. Metellus earned a B.S. in Business Administration, Marketing, with a minor in International Studies. Inspired by her late grandmother, Hermite Gabriel, she mentors students and advocates for environmental justice, housing, education and greater representation for Black, Brown and immigrant communities. 
 
 
   
 
 
 Meet the Honorees 
 
 Thomas Green ’96 ‘01 MA  is a technologist and instructor at Montclair State University, holding both a Bachelor’s and Master’s from Montclair along with multiple professional certifications. A senior member of the Office of Information Technology, he has advanced campus technology and multimedia solutions while promoting student success as a freshman seminar instructor. He also advises Phi Beta Sigma and Zeta Phi Beta, bringing nearly three decades of fraternal leadership experience, including reactivating MSU’s Phi Beta Sigma chapter. 
   
 
 Keyla Silva-Byrd ‘10  graduated with a Psychology major, a minor in African American Studies and a certification in Child Advocacy, and was active in Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, NASO, Team Nicaragua and other campus organizations. She founded the nonprofit Inda Cares, Inc., dedicated to improving education, health and life skills for children in Angola, including projects distributing mosquito nets, school supplies, medical equipment and building plans for a school and community center. She earned her MSW from NYU and has 14 years of experience as a therapist and social worker, currently practicing privately and online. Keyla is a mother of two, married and continues her humanitarian work while valuing her Montclair State roots. 
   
   
 What is BAAC? The Black Alumni Advisory Council (BAAC) connects Montclair State University alumni to current students to share knowledge, offer mentorship, and amplify social justice and inclusion in the community. We honor the strength of our shared roots while supporting the rise of empowered futures. 
 . 
 
   
 What is the African American Caucus of Montclair State University? 
 Awareness, Advocacy, and Change  The African American Caucus (AAC) of Montclair State University serves as a forum for discussion and advocacy regarding matters and issues important to faculty, staff, and students of African descent at Montclair State University. 
   
 What is African American Studies? 
 The African American Studies Minor is an interdisciplinary program.  Students examine the contributions people of African descent have made to human and world history. Courses critically analyze a wide range of philosophies, cultural experiences, social issues, leadership models and solutions to social problems. The program builds on the African American Studies scholar-activist tradition. Students explore education as a means not only for creating personal success but for developing stronger societies rooted in respect for diversity and human rights. 
   
 Got questions? Contact  The Office of Alumni Engagement at alumni@montclair.edu or 973-655-4141 
 This is your chance to level up your career game – don’t miss it!

description:

 Being comfortable in the water

 Learning how to tread water

 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: Rooted in Power
description:
A Civic Engagement Tabling Experience 
   
 Rooted in Power  is an interactive tabling event that invites students to explore where their power comes from—and how their values, identities, and lived experiences shape their role in civic life. Grounded in the idea that lasting change begins at the roots, this event encourages reflection, conversation, and connection around personal and collective power. 
   
 Through engaging prompts and hands-on activities, students will examine the issues they care about most, how those issues connect to their communities, and the ways civic participation—like voting, advocacy, and dialogue—can turn values into action. Whether you’re deeply engaged or just beginning to explore your civic voice, Rooted in Power meets you where you are. 
   
 ✨  What to Expect: 
 
 
 Interactive prompts to reflect on values, identity, and community 
 
 
 Opportunities to explore how personal experiences connect to civic power 
 
 
 Nonpartisan resources to learn how change happens at the local level 
 
 
 A welcoming, judgment-free space for conversation and curiosity 
 
 
   
 Rooted in Power  reminds us that power isn’t just something we see—it’s something we grow, nurture, and use together.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Midweek Series - Strings Studio Recital
description:
Cali Midweek Series: Strings Studio Recital 
 Spend a cold winter Midweek hour wrapped in the gorgeous sounds of strings and the great Romantic composers— Brahms, Elgar, Grieg,  lesser-known Croatian composer  Dora Pejačević  and  Tchaikovsky .  
 Cali’s string faculty will join Cali students, Orpheus-style, for the two glorious inner movements of Tchaikovsky’s Serenade for Strings to conclude the concert. One of Tchaikovsky’s most popular works for musicians and audiences alike, it pairs an enchanting, ascending-scale waltz with a radiant Élégie whose major key turns lament into warm nostalgia. 
 ------------ 
 Cali Midweek Concerts 2025-26 Most Wednesdays at 2 PM Chapin Hall, Leshowitz Recital Hall 
 FREE ADMISSION! 
 Join us for the  Cali Midweek Concerts at Montclair State University’s John J. Cali School of Music , where we bring a diverse array of musical performances and educational events every Wednesday at 2PM in Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall. Our concert series showcases the immense talent within our faculty, students, and esteemed guest artists. 
 FULL SCHEDULE:  https://www.montclair.edu/music/cali-midweek-series-schedule/

title: Spilling Sustainabili-TEA: Celebrating Sustainable Black History and Culture
description:
Join the Office of Sustainability as we present Spilling Sustainabili-Tea: Celebrating Sustainable Black History and Culture.  Sustainable Black Culture  explores how Black communities have historically sustained themselves through creativity, shared knowledge, advocacy, and cultural preservation. Long before sustainability became a modern movement, Black communities practiced resourcefulness, environmental care, and cultural resilience as a way of life. This workshop highlights those traditions and invites participants to reflect on how sustainability is deeply rooted in Black history. 
 Participants will move through a mix of educational activities designed to spark reflection, connection, and learning.

title: Thrift and Gift
description:
Do you have any gently used items that you no longer want? Clear out your closets and find something new for you at the Environmental Club's Thrift & Gift event! This is your chance to give away gently used clothing, books, art supplies decor, cds, vinyls, DVDs, and more, and find something that you want to take home, all while supporting sustainability and reducing waste.  ALL OF THESE ARE FREE!!! 
 Date:  February 18th Time:  2:10 PM - 3:10 PM Location:  Center of Environmental and Life Science (CELS), Room 110 
 Bring your pre-loved items to trade or browse and see what catches your eye. It’s a great way to refresh your wardrobe, find a new favorite book, or stock up on art supplies without spending a dime. Enjoy a fun, friendly atmosphere, meet new people and give old items a new life. 
 Let’s come together to create a more sustainable community. We can't wait to see you there! ♻️✨ 
 PS:  There is going to be free snacks and refreshments. You are not required to bring anything to attend the event, but feel free to do so!

This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Sacher Distinguished Lecture 2026 - Power and Vulnerability in Mozart’s Magic Flute and Requiem Mass with Catherine Coppola
description:
Sacher Distinguished Lecture 2026 
 Power and Vulnerability in Mozart’s  Magic Flute  and Requiem Mass with  Catherine Coppola 
 Date:  Wednesday, February 18, 2026 Time:  3:30 PM Location:  Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall Venue:   John J. Cali School of Music ,  Montclair State University Admission:  Free and open to the public 
 The Sacher Distinguished Lecture in Music is an annual event at the John J. Cali School of Music that features innovative scholarship about music as a cultural form. The lecture takes place in Leshowitz Recital Hall and is free and open to the public. 
 This year’s lecture,  Power and Vulnerability in Mozart’s  Magic Flute  and Requiem Mass , explores how these two landmark works reveal contrasting and overlapping ideas of authority, emotion, and human fragility. 
 Within the span of just a few months in 1791, Mozart completed the opera that would become one of the most performed worldwide and began work on the Requiem that remains a staple of choral performance. Though geared toward different audiences — secular and sacred — both works illuminate shared themes of vulnerability and power. This talk examines how gender, class, and race are intertwined with who gets to wield power, historically and today; considers counter-stories within the works that critique their assumptions; and surveys recent stagings to contextualize creative choices in the Cali Opera production. 
 Operatic in emotional depth, the Requiem offers another perspective on vulnerability in the face of power — not the power of rulers in  The Magic Flute , but the divine, expressed in the  Rex Tremendae  in G minor, a key Mozart reserved for especially charged emotional expression. The lecture concludes with how such awareness can deepen authentic performance and interpretation of both works. 
 About the Speaker Catherine Coppola is Chair of the Thomas Hunter Honors Program at Hunter College (CUNY) and a scholar of opera, canon formation, and pedagogy. Her work appears in leading collections on Mozart and Beethoven. Her forthcoming book,  Teaching Canonic Opera and Musical Theater with Intention  (Routledge, 2026), has been widely praised for its critical insight and practical impact.

title: Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art and Design is excited to announce the opening of the  Fashion Illustration and Digital Applications Exhibition . Students' work will be on view at the Finley Gallery from February 5 through February 19 with the opening reception on Wednesday, February 11 from 2pm-4pm.  
   
 This exhibition features original design illustrations and presentation layouts from courses in the Fashion Design and Merchandising program, including Fashion Illustration, Digital Applications for Fashion, Flat Pattern, and Draping. 
   
 Students design, create, develop, and prepare 2D original visuals that can become 3D professionally executed looks. The fashion design students develop original illustrations to demonstrate their extensive design knowledge by using programs Adobe Illustrator and Adobe Photoshop in tandem with traditional illustration and rendering techniques by hand.  
   
 Each work selected depicts the range of creative possibilities utilizing the process of fashion design. From the initial steps of conception to a sketch, from an illustration to brand & product development, and finally garment construction, students showcase their creative voices as the emerging talent and future of the fashion apparel industry. 
   
 Come view and support the work of Fashion’s next generation of designers and creatives! 
   
 FASHION ILLUSTRATION AND DIGITAL APPLICATIONS EXHIBITION 
 Finley Gallery, Finley Hall 
 Exhibition dates: 2/5-2/19 
 Opening Reception: 2/11 2pm-4pm

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: 2026 Legislative Breakfast: Human Trafficking at the Intersection of Sports
description:
Join us for the 4th Annual Legislative Breakfast  as Montclair State University convenes leaders, advocates, and the campus community to confront human trafficking in New Jersey and explore pathways for real change. 
 Now in its fourth year, the Legislative Breakfast brings together policymakers, survivor leaders, academics, students, and community partners for timely, solutions-oriented conversations at the intersection of research, policy, and practice. This is a unique opportunity for the MSU community to engage directly with issues shaping law, advocacy, and prevention efforts across the state. 
 This year’s theme,  “Human Trafficking at the Intersection of Sports,”  examines the often-overlooked risks connected to major sporting events. From labor exploitation in construction, hospitality, and event operations to increased vulnerabilities during large-scale tournaments, the conversation moves beyond headlines to focus on evidence-based policy responses and accountability. 
 Last year’s sold-out breakfast featured nationally recognized experts, survivor leaders, and New Jersey legislators—and this year’s program promises equally compelling dialogue and actionable insights. Students and staff alike are encouraged to attend, learn, and be part of a growing campus-wide commitment to prevention, awareness, and informed action. For any questions, please reach out to gcht@montclair.edu 
 
 
 
 
 -------------------------------------- Agenda 
 8:00 AM - 9:00 AM |  Registration Opens 
 9:15 AM - 9:45 AM |  Opening Remarks 
 9:45 AM - 10:15 AM |  4th Annual Smith/Wellstone Award Ceremony 
 10:15 AM - 10:30 AM |  Networking Break 
 10:30 AM - 11:45 AM |  Human Trafficking at the Intersection of Sports 
 11:45 AM - 12:30 PM |  Closing Remarks and Networking If you plan to attend the full event and would like a name badge,  please register on Eventbrite. This event is free and open to all.  ---- 
 This event is brought you by the Global Center on Human Trafficking at Montclair State University, along with its co-sponsors: - Montclair State University 
 
 College of Humanities and Social Sciences 
 Department of Justice Studies 
 Department of Social Work and Child Advocacy 
 Office of Government Relations 
 Department of Athletics 
 Department of Recreation 
 
 - It's a Penalty - Mission89 - Covenant House NJ - Family Service League - LSNJ - New Jersey Coalition Against Human Trafficking

title: Civic MatchMaker Tabling
description:
Swipe Right on Your Civic Voice! 
 Have you ever wanted to better understand your own views—and how they align with politics, public policy, and civic life?  Civic Matchmaker  is a fun, welcoming, and low-pressure tabling experience designed to help you explore what matters most to you and how those values connect to the world around you. 
   
 Stop by to answer a few quick, interactive “match-style” prompts that highlight your priorities on issues like education, social justice, the economy, healthcare, climate, and community well-being. As you make your selections, you’ll see how your perspectives align with broader civic and political themes—helping demystify politics and make it feel more personal and relevant. 
   
 ✨  What to Expect: 
 
 
 Engaging, easy-to-answer prompts focused on values and issues 
 
 
 A snapshot of how your views align with civic and political topics 
 
 
 Opportunities to learn how people turn values into action 
 
 
 Nonpartisan resources to help you stay informed and involved 
 
 
 A relaxed, judgment-free space to ask questions and explore 
 
 
   
 No debates. No pressure. Just meaningful self-reflection, discovery, and conversation. Whether you’re deeply engaged or just starting to figure out where you stand,  Civic Matchmaker  helps you connect your values to civic life—and take the next step toward using your voice with confidence. 💬🗳️

description:
Your space to learn, ask & explore at your own pace Hear directly from the people who teach, support, and shape each of Montclair's 200+ graduate programs.  Virtual Graduate Open House  gives you the space to explore quietly or jump into conversations whenever you feel ready. Here's what we've got lined up on Sunday, February 22:  
 
 Join live, program-specific sessions with faculty who are leaders in their field  
 Get guidance on admissions, financial aid, and student support 
 Learn about pathways for career changers, working professionals, and international students 
 
 Did you know?  If you attend a session, you can apply to Montclair for free. The $60 application fee will be waived as our thank you for spending time with us. This could be your moment to discover which programs feel like a natural fit. We hope you can tune in!

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Double Reed Day 2026
description:
Double Reed Day 2026 
 Sunday, February 22, 2026 9:00 AM–5:00 PM John J. Cali School of Music, Montclair State University 
 The John J. Cali School of Music invites oboists, bassoonists, students, educators, and community members to  Double Reed Day 2026 , a full-day celebration of double reed performance, pedagogy, and community. 
 This free, immersive event features masterclasses, ensemble rehearsal, vendor exhibits, instrument repair services, and a culminating concert, with special guest artists  Robert Wagner  (bassoon) and  James Austin Smith  (oboe).

title: Rent In Concert | Musical in Concert | Produced by AMP Worldwide
description:
Experience the iconic music of  RENT  like never before. In this sweeping symphonic concert produced by AMP Worldwide, a powerhouse ensemble of vocalists and instrumentalists brings Jonathan Larson’s groundbreaking rock musical to life in a sweeping symphonic concert. Featuring the full score—including “Seasons of Love,” “La Vie Bohème,” and “Take Me or Leave Me”—this electrifying performance celebrates the enduring spirit of love, loss, and chosen family. 
   
 Set in New York City’s East Village at the height of the HIV/AIDS crisis,  RENT  follows a group of young artists as they chase their dreams, navigate heartbreak, and fight to live—and love—fully in the moment. Winner of the Tony Award for Best Musical and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama,  RENT  remains a cultural touchstone with music that resonates across generations. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Carolyn Enger, Piano Masterclass
description:
We are privileged to have  pianist Carolyn Enger  teach a piano Master Class in Leshowitz Recital Hall. This will take place from 12:00pm until 2:00pm on  Monday, February 23, 2026 . All are welcome. Reservations are not necessary. 
 Internationally celebrated American pianist Carolyn Enger has gained critical acclaim for her exquisite lyrical playing, as well as her deeply felt interpretations.  The New York Times  selected her Naxos recording of intimate Ned Rorem miniatures,  Piano Album I & Six Friends , as one of the newspaper’s “Best In Classical Recordings.” 
 Her latest recording,  Resonating Earth  was released in September 2024 to glowing praise: “a thoughtful programme…enthralling” (Nigel Simone,  International Piano ), “lovingly performed…a beautiful, meaningful recital” (Steve Smith,  Night After Night , “sensitively performed and intelligently curated” (Frances Wilson,  Interlude ), and has been streamed over 500,000 times on Apple Music.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Monday: 1-2PM & 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: All In: The Fight for Democracy
description:
Join us for a powerful screening of  All In for Democracy — The Stacey Abrams Story , a documentary that explores the modern fight for voting rights through the work and leadership of Stacey Abrams. The film examines the barriers to participation that persist in American democracy and highlights the grassroots organizing, advocacy, and resilience behind efforts to expand access to the ballot. 
   
 Through compelling storytelling and real-world examples, this screening invites viewers to reflect on the importance of civic participation, the impact of voter suppression, and the role individuals and communities play in strengthening democracy. Following the screening, participants are encouraged to engage in conversation and reflection around civic responsibility, equity, and democratic engagement. 
   
 This event is open to all and designed to foster learning, dialogue, and a deeper understanding of how democracy works—and how it can be protected and strengthened.

title: upLIFT
description:
Step into the brand-new PLAE Room and discover upLIFT—a judgement-free program designed to help every student, from complete beginners to seasoned gym-goers, feel confident and capable with free-weight training. Whether you’re looking to meet other students who love to lift, pursue new fitness goals, or simply feel more at home in the weight room, upLIFT offers a supportive community and a dedicated space to grow. The program is structured for steady progression throughout the semester, but you’re welcome to drop in anytime and join at your own pace.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 Tuesday: 5-6PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water

 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps

title: Community and Social Services Career Expo
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
Community and Social Services Career Expo Date:  February 24, 2026 Time:  3:30pm-6:30pm Location:  University Hall Conference Center (7th Floor) 
 Pre-registration is strongly encouraged -  Register on Handshake ! 
 Calling all community and service-minded students exploring clinical and non-clinical career options! 
 Are you looking for a job or internship? Are you curious about the career paths you can pursue with your major or graduate program? If so, the Community and Social Services Career Expo is an amazing opportunity to meet employers that align with your professional interests. Whether you are a freshman or a graduate student, this event is designed to help you explore career possibilities, gain networking experience by talking with employers, and make connections that may eventually lead to a job or internship. There will be fun mixed in with the opportunity to win raffle prizes, and Rocky, Roxy, or Pebbles might even stop by! 
 More Information: - Visit with non-profit, government, and corporate employers that have a service-oriented mission - Discover opportunities with campus organizations and departments, including international experiences that incorporate social impact - Event details and employer list can be found on  Handshake . - Dress neatly and bring resumes! Check out Rocky's Closet for free professional attire. 
 This event is ideal for graduate and undergraduate students seeking jobs and internships in: Counseling, Child Advocacy, Justice Studies, Social Work, Political Science, Psychology and so much more! 
   
 Co-sponsored by:  College of Humanities and Social Sciences, College for Community Health, Office of Community Engagement and Partnerships, Office of Experiential Education and Career Connections, Office of Government Relations, Office of International Academic Initiatives 
   
 Questions? Contact Jennifer Dudeck-Lenis at  dudecklenisj@montclair.edu.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Food & God!
location: University Hall 1010 - James B. Todd Lecture Hall
description:
Cru is a caring community of students passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us for Food & God - an open and inviting space where you can explore faith, ask questions, and engage in meaningful conversations—all over a delicious meal. This event is not about debating or convincing; it’s about listening, sharing, and creating a space where everyone feels heard and respected. Whether you have deep spiritual questions, doubts, or just want to hear different perspectives, you are welcome here. 
 As you enjoy your meal, we’ll dive into honest discussions about life, God, and what it all means. There’s no pressure, no expectations—just real talk in a relaxed and judgment-free environment. We believe that great conversations happen over great food, and this is an opportunity to connect with others in a way that is both thought-provoking and welcoming. 
 So come hungry, bring a friend, and join us for an afternoon of free food, good company, and genuine conversations. We’d love to hear your thoughts, share our experiences, and explore faith together—one plate at a time.

title: NASO General Body Meeting
description: Join us for the Native African Student Organization's General Body Meeting! This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Free Swim Lessons *Intermediate*
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
   
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester, we will be focusing on the theme  "Identity in Christ."  We pray that our students will learn more about who they are in Christ, and look at some examples of people in the Bible where God revealed their true identity in Christ! 
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

description:

title: Ghost Lake Hike (Moderate)
description:
This Haunted Hike at Ghost Lake in Jenny Jump State Park will send you running for the hills! Whether you believe in ghosts or not, this is a hauntingly beautiful hike. This moderately rated 5.7 mile loop has great views of mountains and valleys before arriving at the lake. Some say that a Native American burial ground lies below the surface.   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register in the Student Recreation Center main office or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students  $10  
 Faculty/Staff/ $20 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, February 21, 2026 
 10a.m. - 4 p.m. 
 Begins Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, bug spray, sunscreen, layered clothing (depending on weather) and close-toe shoes (sneakers) 
 Potential Hazards:  Poisonous plants/allergies; insect bites; unpredictable weather changes; sunburn/heat exhaustion; dehydration; steep, rocky and/or slippery terrain; rolling or falling rocks; snakes and large animals; and injuries including sprains/strains, abrasions, lacerations and fractures.

title: A Cross-Generational Conversation with Alumni Artists
location: George Segal Gallery, 4th Floor of the Red Hawk Deck
description:
Admission is free, open to the public.  Learn more about this exhibition 
   
 This multi-generational panel celebrates the distinguished women alumni of Montclair. Featuring exhibiting artists Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, and Maria Valdivia ’24 in conversation about their careers and creative practices, moderated by curator Sally Morgan Lehman. 
   
 Carpe Diem: Select Alumni in the Visual Arts  is a group exhibition presented by the Office for Development and Alumni Engagement and hosted by the University Galleries.  Carpe Diem  brings together twelve accomplished alumni working in a range of media. 
   
 Curated by Sally Morgan Lehman, who has taught in the Department of Art and Design at Montclair and is owner and director of Morgan Lehman Gallery in New York City,  Carpe Diem  highlights the breadth of artistic practices fostered at Montclair and the lasting impact of its visual arts alumni. 
   
 Featured artists include Flávia Berindoague ’13, Bisa Butler ’05, Jonathan Calm ’97, Kyle Coniglio ’10, Alyssa Fanning ’12, Allen Ginsberg (1943), Márta Kucsora (2005–06), Michael Manning ’11, Nancy Bergman Pantirer ’80, Tiffany Perez ’09, William Pope.L ’78, and Maria Valdivia ’24.

Each meeting is a chance to be seen, heard, and supported while building lasting connections.

title: MSU Political Science Club General Body Meeting
description: Join us for our General Body Meetings every Wednesday from 2:00 to 3:15 p.m. in Dickson Hall, Room 272! Engage in vibrant discussions about domestic and international politics, where all students are welcome to share their thoughts. Each meeting includes a research presentation followed by open discussion, encouraging diverse perspectives and debates. Don't miss this opportunity to deepen your understanding of political issues and connect with fellow students!

title: Haitian Student Association General Body Meeting
description: Sak Pase! Welcome back to another great semester with your favorite Zoes on campus! Come chill with us every week as we go beyond the culture and tackle college life, personal life and serious topics in the world of a college student today. Although we are a culturally Haitian-based Organization, all are loved and all are welcomed! find us in room 2026 Wednesday, 2:00-3:30!

title: NASO General Body Meeting
description: Join us for the Native African Student Organization's General Body Meeting! This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: The DJ Academy: Music Matters 101
description:
DJing is one of the original elements of Hip Hop and is often considered the first. Hip Hop began in the Bronx during the 1970s at community block parties, where DJs used turntables to bring people together through music. Early pioneers like DJ Kool Herc introduced breakbeats by looping the most rhythmic parts of records, creating the foundation for breaking and shaping how dancers and MCs interacted with the music. 
 As Hip Hop evolved, DJing became the musical backbone of the culture. DJs provide the beats for MCing, set the tempo for dancers, and control the energy of Hip Hop spaces by reading the crowd and responding in real time. Through techniques like scratching, cutting, and beat juggling, DJs helped define Hip Hop’s sound while preserving its history and passing down cultural knowledge. 
 This class introduces the basics of DJing and how music shapes the dance experience. DJ Bascis will explain core concepts such as  tempo, rhythm, and song structure , helping students understand how music guides movement and energy on the dance floor. 
 Participants will learn how DJs choose music, create smooth transitions, and adjust the vibe based on the room.  
 Through simple examples and live demonstrations, students will build confidence in listening to music with intention. This can bewhether they are dancing, freestyling, or interested in DJing themselves. 
 This class is designed for  beginners and college students , with no prior DJ or music experience required.
